instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that came in as no power due to liquid damage. I found surface corrosion around <CHIP>U8330</CHIP> and SMC. Stone dead with PPBUS at 12.23V. I found the trace for <RESISTOR>R5170</RESISTOR> (<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>) was broken so I ran a jumper. I also ran a wire to <RESISTOR>R5173</RESISTOR>. I now have PPBUS at 12.59V, PP3V42 is 3.42V, etc. I checked all the power rails and found them up to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message:
If you get into S4 state, power on sequence is started by PCH; as it released <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> signal.
Are you sure no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> present?
Check for pulse at least, when you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: I'm not getting <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>. I'll check if I am getting <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: i think I am getting 2 little jumps on my multi-meter. I'll check with a scope later to confirm. The last digit on my DMM goes from 0 to 1 when I turn on power supply.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message:
"I checked all the power rails and found them up to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>."
Seems that I wrong understood you; I assumed it is present.
Be more explicit when you post...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: Ok. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is zero volts.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message:
Post the basic signals which we always mention for power sequence.
Use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads to trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, instead of power button.
Test with trackpad/KB disconnected, nor RIO flex.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message:
3v3-sus:                       3.3v
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>:                  0v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>:       3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>:      3.42v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>:           3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>:           3.42v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>:           .036v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>:            3.41v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 0v
--------------------
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 3.42v"
Can explain that???
Read the note at page 64.

"<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>: .036v"
Are you using correct original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: I do not see the note on page 64 you are talking about. and yes I am using original charger. I am not familiar with <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>. The board is out of the chassis if that makes sense.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: Search for <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> in pdf and read the note near it on page 64...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: OHHHHH, I get it now. <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes to the SMC then the SMC puts out <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. So you cannot really have <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> without <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: I wonder what I did to not get the correct measurement for <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> then.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message:
Check again the signals.
If possible, test the same signal in different points; this way can discard broken trace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: Ok, i will try that. I take it I am just looking for <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and not the others since they are present. Just want to make doubly sure.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: Ironically enough, <RESISTOR>R5192</RESISTOR> is the exact resistor I had to run a wire to... That resistor is for <SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD_VIN</SIGNAL>. That was one of the two spots with blown probe points.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: I'm thinking that doesn't have anything to do with the issue though...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message:
Did you reball SMC?
If not, is time to do it.

Be sure no more broken traces...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: I did a light SMC reflow last night. I will reball it tonight.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: with some Amtech flux

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: Sorry, had to change post. after reballing the SMC the computer now boots. I'm going to clean it up and put it back together and test it. Thank you so much for your guidance, and patients...This one looks to be solved.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message:
PCH will not start power on sequence if <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is kept low.
Try another 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger; NOT adapter 1->2.

Does it charge the battery?
Try to start when battery and charger both connected.

Did you try SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange light, not turning on.
threads.message: yes i used an original 60w charger. <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is now 3.3V and the computer is running great.
